abstract.p: Intel and National Basketball Association will create combined venture that will include broadband progamming and interactive game broadcasts; deal would give fans access to daily NBA and WNBA highlights as well as archived; NBA will receive 10 percent equity stake in Convera, company formed by Intel and Excalibur Technologies, and NBA Comr David Stern will join company's board of directors; photo (S)

block.p: Intel and the National Basketball Association announced an agreement yesterday to create a combined venture that will include broadband programming and interactive game broadcasts. Officials said the deal would give fans access to daily N.B.A. and W.N.B.A. highlights as well as archived N.B.A. highlights. In May, Intel, the world's largest computer chip maker, and Excalibur Technologies, an Internet company, announced that they would form a new company, the Convera Corporation, to enable owners of valuable content to produce and securely sell audio, video and other information. According to the agreement yesterday, the N.B.A. will receive a 10 percent equity stake in Convera and the basketball association's commissioner, David Stern, will join the company's board of directors.
